column1: Logic Attention Based Neighborhood Aggregation for Inductive Knowledge Graph Embedding
AAAI Technical Track: Natural Language Processing
Knowledge graph embedding aims at modeling entities and relations with low-dimensional vectors. Most previous methods require that all entities should be seen during training
column2: which is unpractical for real-world knowledge graphs with new entities emerging on a daily basis. Recent efforts on this issue suggest training a neighborhood aggregator in conjunction with the conventional entity and relation embeddings
column3: which may help embed new entities inductively via their existing neighbors. However
column4: their neighborhood aggregators neglect the unordered and unequal natures of an entity’s neighbors. To this end
column5: we summarize the desired properties that may lead to effective neighborhood aggregators. We also introduce a novel aggregator
column8: which addresses the properties by aggregating neighbors with both rules- and network-based attention weights. By comparing with conventional aggregators on two knowledge graph completion tasks
column9: we experimentally validate LAN’s superiority in terms of the desired properties.
